title: Chawton Park Wood Walking Route

images.title: Graham Clutton / Chawton Park Woods
images.caption: Chawton Park Woods. Most of the wood seems to be conifers but the park is quite old with Park Pales marked on the map

images.title: Graham Clutton / Picnic Area at Chawton Park Woods
images.caption: Picnic Area at Chawton Park Woods. There is a car park here a short way from the A31. It provides good access to the walks in the woods. Unfortunately the picnic benches seem to have vanished!

images.title: Graham Clutton / Cycle path near Chawton Park Woods
images.caption: Cycle path near Chawton Park Woods. This path has been recently upgraded to form a traffic free route between Alton and Four Marks. It's now good enough for my normal bike as well as mountain bikes.

images.title: Graham Clutton / Chawton Park Farm
images.caption: Chawton Park Farm. A lovely spot in a quiet valley quite near Alton. There is a duck pond, sheep in a barn and lovely fields. There is now a cycle path up through the woods to Four Marks.

images.title: Peter Trimming / Chawton House
images.caption: Chawton House. The Manor House on a rare public open day.

images.title: Derek Harper / Chawton
images.caption: Chawton village.  To the left of the Greyhound pub is a terrace of listed cottages of the late C18

images.title: Tony Grant / Jane Austen's House
images.caption: Jane Austen's House. Jane Austen lived here with her mother and sister Cassandra.The house belonged to one of her brothers, an officer in the Royal Navy. She wrote a couple of her novels here including Mansfield Park. It was here that she took ill and travelled to Winchester where she died in her doctors house, close to the precincts of Winchester Cathedral.

description: Enjoy a circular walk around this large area of woodland in Hampshire. The woods are located just to the west of the town of Alton and have miles of footpaths, tracks and bridleways to try. You can start the walk at the south western corner of the woods where there is a public car park (postcode GU34 5ED). It's located close to Medstead and Four Marks Railway Station so you could also start from their if you prefer. From the car park you can pick up the trails heading east towards Chawton village before following alternative trails back to form a circular walk. It's a peaceful spot and very pretty in the spring where there are lots of bluebells to see. Also keep your eyes for a variety of woodland birds as you make your way along the trails.
